thread.title: Unrestricted pumping declared for Carnarvon farmers
thread.title_full: Unrestricted pumping declared for Carnarvon farmers

author: Matt Brann
title: Unrestricted pumping declared for Carnarvon farmers
text:
Map: Carnarvon 6701 
Farmers in Carnarvon have been quick to act on the WA Department of Water's decision to allow unrestricted pumping from the riverbed sands aquifer of the lower Gascoyne River. 
The Gascoyne River started flowing through the farming community of Carnarvon on Sunday, February 5 and reached a level on Friday that triggered the unrestricted pumping. 
The declaration is for the remainder of February and is the first time growers have had unlimited access to the river in almost two years. 
Banana grower Bruce Munro said many farmers had their pumps ready to go as soon as the declaration was issued. 
"It's coming up nearly two years since we've seen the river flowing like this, so we've been really looking forward to this," he said. 
"For my property there's still a lot of dry sand between me and the water, but obviously there's a lot of growers who can take full advantage of it." Photo: The Gascoyne River flowing under the Nine Mile Bridge, Feb 10. (Supplied: Department of Water) 
Mr Munro hoped the river flow would flush-out the salty water, which has plagued the irrigation area since 2010. 
"The unrestricted pumping of this quality water means a lot, because our water has a certain amount of salt in it, and the more salt you put on the bananas, it does affect your yields," he said. 
"So the fresher the water the better, and this flow is really good. 
"I'm looking forward to good yields and this river flow will sure-up [Carnarvon's] water-supply for the next 18 months." 
Troy Sinclair from the Department of Water in Carnarvon said the unrestricted pumping would be reviewed at the start of March. 
"So if the river is still flowing in March we'll keep unrestricted pumping going provided the water quality is still good enough," he said. 
"Given the forecast is looking fairly wet for the next week or so, lets hope we can continue this through to March when a lot of the planting starts to happen."
